description.narrative: The projects overall objective is to mobilise youths energy, mobility, open-mindedness and dynamism as a potential positive force of countering violent extremist influences and narratives in the target communities affected by radicalisation.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1.1: Youth engagement platforms developed and support cooperation between key local actors in 7 districts and 6 cities in Kazakhstan 1.1.1 An assessment of barriers to youth integration in local labour markets - 1 1.1.2 Number of local youth initiatives supported through small grants scheme and implemented by youth - 18 1.1.3 Number of Youth Action platforms providing technical and advising support - 2 1.1.4 Number of social support counsellors underwent specialised trainings - 120 1.1.5 Number of trained and equipped district policemen, school administrations, teachers and social service providers - 144 1.1.6 Number of self-made youth opinion leaders trained to work with at-risk youth - 20
Output 2.1 Enhancing job and income opportunities through peer-to-peer support groups for at least 500 young people in vulnerable communities in 6 selected cities of Kazakhstan 2.1.1 Number of youth benefitted from subsidised apprenticeships - 500 2.1.2 Number of youth benefitted from applied trainings - 500 2.1.3 Number of sustainable jobs created through small grants scheme and specialised training and licensing to provide technical support to introduction of energy efficiency/ saving measures - 60 2.1.4 . Number of young people benefited from specialised trainings - 60
Output 3. Regional youth networks established, knowledge sharing on PVE intensified 3.1 Number of training tools and materials for awareness raising and counselling on early signs of the radicalisation - 2 3.2 Number of regional dialogues using both virtual and physical platforms to elicit, critically assess and summarize lessons learned on PVE - 2 3.3 Number of regional youth initiatives and exchanges on implementation of SDGs, especially SDG16 - 1 3.4 Analytical reports on the drivers of PVE and the linkages with employment and social inclusion - 2 3.5 Number of high level regional meetings for exchange of knowledge and experience on PVE - 0

Output 1.1: Youth engagement platforms developed and support cooperation between key local actors in 7 districts and 6 cities in Kazakhstan benefiting at least 1,000 young people 1.1.1 An assessment of barriers to youth integration in local labour markets - 0 1.1.2 Number of local youth initiatives supported through small grants scheme and implemented by youth - 6 1.1.3 Number of Youth Action platforms providing technical and advising support - 0 1.1.4 Number of social support counsellors underwent specialised trainings - 0 1.1.5 Number of trained and equipped district policemen, school administrations, teachers and social service providers - 13 1.1.6 Number of self-made youth opinion leaders trained to work with at-risk youth - 0
Output 2.1: Enhancing job and income opportunities through peer-to-peer support groups for at least 500 young people in vulnerable communities in 6 selected cities of Kazakhstan 2.1.1 Number of youth benefitted from subsidised apprenticeships - 100 2.1.2 Number of youth benefitted from applied trainings - 100 2.1.3 Number of sustainable jobs created through small grants scheme and specialised training and licensing to provide technical support to introduction of energy efficiency/ saving measures - 20 2.1.4 . Number of young people benefited from specialised trainings - 18
Output 3: Regional youth networks established and knowledge sharing on PVE will be enhanced 3.1 Number of training tools and materials for awareness raising and counselling on early signs of the radicalisation - 0 3.2 Number of regional dialogues using both virtual and physical platforms to elicit, critically assess and summarize lessons learned on PVE - 1 3.3 Number of regional youth initiatives and exchanges on implementation of SDGs, especially SDG16 - 1 3.4 Analytical reports on the drivers of PVE and the linkages with employment and social inclusion - 3 3.5 Number of high level regional meetings for exchange of knowledge and experience on PVE - 1

Major achievements under Output 1.1: - Upskilling programmes implemented for 27 front-line service providers daily interacting with vulnerable youth at risk of radicalization (psychologists, vice-principles of schools and colleges, youth resource centers and district policemen) in 6 select localities. - 6 youth opinion leaders shared personal life experiences and positive life scenarios with 939 vulnerable youth. - 1 Coworking Center were opened in project target areas to support social business projects for young vulnerable people and local community in select localities. - 4 Street Workout Grounds were launched by the local NGOs to provide health benefits to people in 4 locations across the regions: in Aktobe oblast’s Shalkar and Shubarkuduk, in Karaganda oblast’s Satpayev and Balkhash with one sports ground fully restored, and another Transforming Sports Ground opened in Balkhash. - 2 Youth Development Centers were opened in both Aktobe and Karaganda oblasts to foster physical, academic and individual growth through community partnerships, engaged mentors and a safe environment. - 2 Sound Recording Studios were opened in Zhezkazgan and Satpayev cities. - Archery Club was for the first time launched in Shalkar, Aktobe oblast. - Boxing Club was opened in Kandyagash, Aktobe oblast.
Major achievements under Output 2.1: - A 3-month subsidized apprenticeship scheme launched in public institutions and private businesses supplemented with weekly accompanying soft skills, professional and gender mainstreamed trainings for 401 vulnerable young people, of them 231 subsequently employed. Local consultations to identify vulnerable youth and potential employers for participation in the scheme have been conducted from the project outset. The proven scheme, previously deployed by UNDP in Balkan countries, was tailored to the Kazakhstan context in consultation with UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub, UNDP CO in Macedonia, Kazakhstan’s Ministry of Labor and Social Protection and local authorities. - Entrepreneurial grants for 32 local businesses commenced with 101 jobs created for vulnerable young people through peer-to-peer support of business initiatives. - Professional trainings organized and conducted for 79 young men and women from Aktobe and Karaganda regions with 42 of them employed after the completion of the programme.
Major achievements under Output 3: - 2 youth exchanges were organized to allow young people to become aware of socially relevant topics and thematic areas in each other’s contexts and increased their intercultural awareness through peer-learning; as well as strengthen values like solidarity, democracy and friendship in the Central Asia region. - Special attention was devoted to enhanced cooperation of stakeholders in CA region. For this purpose, 1 thematic regional dialogue was implemented to foster exchange of knowledge and expertise in PVE. ­ Joint study with UNODC to provide Situational Analysis of Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan’s experience in preparing for, developing and implementing repatriation, rehabilitation and reintegration programs launched and completed. ­ Two joint studies with IOM were launched to analyze socioeconomic vulnerabilities as a factor in long-term risk of radicalization: prevention potential of local communities and official assistance in selected Central Asian regions; and Rapid assessment of the opportunities for decent employment for youth facing long-term exclusion from the labour markets in selected regions of Kazakhstan and Tajikistan. The researches have been completed. ­ A study to generate evidence and provide understanding on the current perceptions and attitudes of young people in Central Asia in relation to socio-economic exclusion was finalized with the Public Policy and Management Institute Group (PPMI Group), the results have established comparable cross-country data to measure impact and can contribute to baselines for future studies on PVE.

Output 1.1: Youth engagement platforms developed and support cooperation between key local actors in 7 districts and 6 cities in Kazakhstan 1.1.1 An assessment of barriers to youth integration in local labour markets - 0 1.1.2 Number of local youth initiatives supported through small grants scheme and implemented by youth - 6 1.1.3 Number of Youth Action platforms providing technical and advising support - 0 1.1.4 Number of social support counsellors underwent specialised trainings - 40 1.1.5 Number of trained and equipped district policemen, school administrations, teachers and social service providers - 48 1.1.6 Number of self-made youth opinion leaders trained to work with at-risk youth - 20

Number of young people benefited from specialised trainings - 42
Output 3. Regional youth networks established, knowledge sharing on PVE intensified 3.1 Number of training tools and materials for awareness raising and counselling on early signs of the radicalisation - 0 3.2 Number of regional dialogues using both virtual and physical platforms to elicit, critically assess and summarize lessons learned on PVE - 2 3.3 Number of regional youth initiatives and exchanges on implementation of SDGs, especially SDG16 - 5 3.4 Analytical reports on the drivers of PVE and the linkages with employment and social inclusion (one large-scale research) - 1 3.5 Number of high level regional meetings for exchange of knowledge and experience on PVE (global PVE event) - 1

Major achievements under Output 1.1: • 6-day Youth Camp for 60 vulnerable young men and women aged 23 – 26 at Suleiman Demirel University located in Kaskelen city of Almaty oblast. • Trainings for 123 front-line service providers (psychologists, vice-principles of schools and colleges, youth resource centers and district policemen) in 6 select localities. • 7 youth opinion leaders met with 230 vulnerable youth in 6 select localities. • 4 Co-Working Centers to support social business projects for young people with deviant behavior in selected localities. • Youth Development Center was opened in Shubarkuduk town to support youth emotional and intellectual growth and improve critical thinking. • “Street Workout” (outdoor sports facilities) to provide health benefits to people living in project select areas. • Jas Orda Youth Center to serve as a dialogue and knowledge platform and to contribute to social, cultural and intellectual development of young people.
Major achievements under Output 2.1: • A 3-month subsidized apprenticeship scheme has been launched in state institutions and private businesses supplemented with the weekly accompanying gender mainstreamed trainings for 175 vulnerable young people. Local consultations to identify vulnerable youth and potential employers for participation in the scheme have been conducted from the project outset. The proven scheme, previously deployed by UNDP in Balkan countries, was tailored to the Kazakhstan context in consultation with UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub, UNDP CO in Macedonia, Kazakhstan’s Ministry of Labor and Social Protection and local authorities. • A “small grants” programme for local businesses has been commenced to create employment opportunities for vulnerable young people through support of entrepreneurial initiatives.
Major achievements under Output 3: • The First Central Asian Younithone on ‘Inclusive policies for youth – opportunities for all’ has been organised in Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan. • The Youth Consultation and Exchange, Second Central Asian Younithone on ‘Youth, Peace and Security in Central Asia took place in Dushanbe, Republic of Tajikistan. • The Central Asian Youth Creative Camp ‘Building bridges’ was held in Issyk-Kul, Kyrgyz Republic. • The Third Regional Dialogue on ‘Effective PVE Programming and Policy: Lessons Learned and Best Practices’ took place in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan. • The project team convened a Technical Working Group meeting (TWG) for Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan as a follow up to Regional Dialogue. • The Fourth Regional Dialogue ‘Emerging Trends in Violent Extremism and Preventive Measures’ conducted in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. • Joint study with UNODC to provide Situational Analysis of Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan’s experience in preparing for, developing and implementing repatriation, rehabilitation and reintegration programs launched. • Joint study with IOM to analyze socioeconomic vulnerabilities as a factor in long-term risk of radicalization: prevention potential of local communities and official assistance in selected Central Asian regions launched. • A study to generate evidence and provide understanding on the current perceptions and attitudes of young people in Central Asia in relation to socio-economic exclusion commenced, the results are expected to measure the progress and impact of the overall project, provide comparable cross-country data and establish a baseline for future studies on the impact of the program.
n/a, all project activities were completed in 2020
n/a, all project activities were completed in 2020
